data.question: How do topical or combined topical/systemic antibiotics compare with topical antiseptics for people with chronic suppurative otitis media?
data.gold_answer: Based on inconsistent or very low‐certainty evidence, we cannot draw any meaningful conclusions about the comparative effects of topical or combined topical/systemic antibiotics versus topical antiseptics for people with chronic suppurative otitis media. Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that topical antibiotics seem more effective than boric acid for increasing rates of resolution of ear discharge (on average, 594 vs 381 per 1000 people). Other comparisons showed similar effects in both groups (very low‐certainty evidence), and one RCT with 100 participants suggested that acetic acid with suction was superior to topical plus systemic antibiotics. However, this RCT reported inadequate randomization and unclear withdrawals.
data.gold_answer_terms:
TOPICAL (topical): on the surface
ANTIBIOTIC (antibiotic): drug that kills bacteria and other germs
ANTIBIOTICS (antibiotics): Medicines to fight an infection caused by bacteria.
CHRONIC (chronic): continuing for a long time, ongoing
RCT (rct): A study which tests the effectiveness and safety of treatments or procedures as fairly and objectively as possible. By randomly assigning patients to different treatments for the same problem, the results can be assessed equally with the aim of discovering the best possible procedure for the condition.
RANDOM (random): by chance (like the flip of a coin)
RANDOMIZATION (randomization): chance selection

The choice of treatment depends on severity, duration, and bacteriology of the infection, as well as patient factors and antibiotic resistance.

Topical antibiotics and topical antiseptics are both effective treatments for chronic suppurative otitis media, but they work in different ways.
Topical antibiotics, such as antibiotic ear drops, work by directly targeting the bacterial infection in the ear and helping to clear it up. They are particularly useful for people who have a bacterial infection that is causing symptoms such as discharge, odor, and pain.
Topical antiseptics, on the other hand, work by reducing the number of bacteria on the skin and in the ear canal, which can help to prevent infection and promote healing. They are often used in combination with antibiotics to enhance their effectiveness.
When comparing topical antibiotics and topical antiseptics, a study published in the Journal of Laryngology and Otology found that topical antibiotics were more effective in treating chronic suppurative otitis media than topical antiseptics. However, the study also noted that the combination of topical antibiotics and antiseptics was more effective than using either treatment alone.
It's important to note that the choice of treatment will depend on the severity and nature of the infection, as well as the individual's medical history and any allergies they may have. It's best to consult with a healthcare professional to determine the most appropriate treatment plan.
In summary, topical antibiotics and topical antiseptics are both effective treatments for chronic suppurative otitis media, but topical antibiotics may be more effective in treating bacterial infections. A combination of both treatments may be the most effective approach. It's important to consult with a healthcare professional to determine the best course of treatment.

data.question: How does blue light compare with white light cystoscopy for adults undergoing transurethral resection of non‐muscle invasive bladder cancer?
data.gold_answer: Blue light cystoscopy may decrease rates of disease recurrence and disease progression in adults with non‐muscle invasive bladder cancer, but probably has little to no effect on adverse events, surgical complications, or rate of bladder cancer death. However, the certainty of the evidence was low for all outcomes. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that when compared with white light cystoscopy, blue light cystoscopy may result in a lower risk of disease recurrence. With risk stratification in terms of disease recurrence, the difference in risk increased with high‐ and intermediate‐risk disease (102 vs 150 per 1000 people with low risk, 271 vs 380 per 1000 people with intermediate risk, and 463 vs 610 per 1000 people with high risk; all results on average). Low‐certainty evidence also suggests that the risk of disease progression may be lower with blue light than with white light cystoscopy. Again, the rates of disease progression decreased depending on baseline risk, with the difference between groups becoming wider with increasing bladder cancer risk (1 vs 2 per 1000 people with low risk, 33 vs 50 per 1000 people with intermediate risk, and 114 vs 170 per 1000 people with high risk). Low‐certainty evidence suggests there may be little to no difference between treatment groups in surgical complication rates, rates of death from bladder cancer, and adverse events.

data.question: For preterm infants with evolving or established bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), what are the effects of late (≥ 7 days) systemic corticosteroids (CSs)?
data.gold_answer: For preterm infants (< 1000 to < 1501 g birthweight and/or < 28 to < 33 weeks' gestation), use of systemic CSs at seven days after birth or later reduced mortality (per 1000 infants, 34 fewer within 28 days, 69 fewer at 36 weeks' postmenstrual age, and 44 fewer at last reported age [high‐certainty evidence]; all results on average), incidence of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (per 1000 infants, 91 fewer within 28 days, and 56 fewer at 36 weeks' postmenstrual age [moderate‐certainty evidence]), requirement for late rescue with CSs (222 fewer per 1000 infants), extubation failures by day 7 (274 fewer per 1000 infants), and requirement for oxygen at home (48 fewer per 1000 infants). However, more infants experienced complications: hyperglycemia (75 more per 1000 infants), hypertension (21 more per 1000 infants), gastrointestinal bleeding (14 more per 1000 infants), hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (50 more per 1000 infants), and/or overall severe retinopathy of prematurity (ROP; 61 more per 1000 infants; the result for severe ROP in survivors was inconclusive). Reviewers stated that no studies were powered to detect increased rates of important adverse long‐term neurodevelopmental outcomes.
data.gold_answer_terms:
GESTATION (gestation): The time between conception and birth, when the fetus grows and develops inside the mother’s womb.
MORTALITY (mortality): death
DYSPLASIA (dysplasia): abnormal cells
COMPLICATIONS (complications): Problems that develop after an operation, treatment or illness.
HYPERTENSION (hypertension): high blood pressure
GASTROINTESTINAL (gastrointestinal): Relating to the stomach and intestine.
data.llm_answer: Late (≥ 7 days) systemic corticosteroids (CSs) in preterm infants with evolving or established bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) have been associated with a reduction in the risk of death or chronic lung disease at 36 weeks' postmenstrual age, but may also be associated with an increased risk of cerebral palsy. However, the optimal dosage and duration of treatment remain unclear. Further research is needed to determine the long-term benefits and risks of CSs in this population.

data.llm_answer:
According to current evidence, late (≥ 7 days) systemic corticosteroids (CSs) in preterm infants with evolving or established bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) may have both positive and negative effects.
Positive effects:
1. Improved lung function: CSs can help reduce inflammation and promote lung maturation, which can improve lung function and reduce the risk of chronic lung disease.
2. Reduced risk of respiratory failure: CSs may help reduce the risk of respiratory failure and the need for mechanical ventilation in preterm infants with BPD.
3. Reduced risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia: CSs may help reduce the risk of developing bronchopulmonary dysplasia, a chronic lung disease that can result from lung injury in preterm infants.
Negative effects:
1. Increased risk of infections: CSs can suppress the immune system, which can increase the risk of infections, particularly in preterm infants who are already at higher risk due to their prematurity.
2. Adrenal insufficiency: Prolonged use of CSs can lead to adrenal insufficiency, a condition in which the adrenal glands do not produce enough cortisol, which can have serious consequences.
3. Growth restriction: CSs can inhibit growth and affect bone development, particularly when used in high doses or for extended periods.
4. Neurodevelopmental delays: CSs can affect brain development and have been associated with neurodevelopmental delays, particularly when used in high doses or for extended periods.
It is important to note that the benefits and risks of late (≥ 7 days) systemic corticosteroids (CSs) in preterm infants with evolving or established bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) can vary depending on the individual infant and the specific clinical situation. The decision to use CSs should be made on a case-by-case basis, taking into account the potential benefits and risks, as well as the infant's overall health and medical history.

data.question: What are the effects of abiraterone acetate as adjunct to androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) for men with metastatic hormone‐sensitive prostate cancer?
data.gold_answer: For men with metastatic hormone‐sensitive prostate cancer, high‐certainty evidence shows that abiraterone acetate as adjunct to androgen deprivation therapy results in improved overall survival (539 vs 702 per 1000 people died at median follow‐up of 30 months; all results on average). Moderate‐certainty evidence shows improvements with abiraterone in prostate cancer mortality (202 vs 322 per 1000 people), disease progression (416 vs 785 per 1000 people), and quality of life (by approx. 3 points on a 0 to 156 scale). However, high‐certainty evidence shows increased rates of grades III to V adverse events with adjunct abiraterone (688 vs 513 per 1000 people), and moderate‐certainty shows that more people discontinued treatment with abiraterone due to adverse events (219 vs 146 per 1000 people).

data.question: How does treatment of periodontitis affect glycemic control in adults with diabetes mellitus?
data.gold_answer: Periodontal treatment for adults with diabetes mellitus may result in improved outcomes when compared with no active intervention or usual care. RCT evidence (mixed risk of bias) shows that periodontal disease treatment in people with diabetes using subgingival instrumentation alone or with the use of local or systemic antimicrobials or antimicrobial mouth rinses, compared with no treatment or usual care, probably offers a beneficial mean reduction of glycosylated hemoglobin values (HbA1c) 3 to 12 months after completion of treatment. For all the other outcomes used to assess periodontal disease improvements, such as gingival index, plaque index, clinical attachment level, bleeding on probing and probing pocket depths, the different periodontal treatments successfully improved periodontitis in people with diabetes, with or without adjuncts such as oral hygiene instruction and antimicrobials. For clinical practice, periodontal treatment alone or with adjuncts compared with no therapy seems to improve the hemoglobin glycosylated HbA1c and periodontal disease parameters in people with diabetes. Any improvements may be valuable, considering that uncontrolled diabetes is known for its detrimental consequences in the periodontal tissues. However, for glycemic control, for example in a person with diabetes with a current HbA1c of 8, after three to four months of periodontal treatment, the HbA1c would be reduced to around 7.97, which might be considered a very modest reduction. The results of the review, particularly regarding glycemic control and the quality of the supporting evidence, should be interpreted with caution by dentists and other healthcare providers for application in clinical practice.

According to the American Diabetes Association, there is a two-way relationship between periodontitis and diabetes mellitus. On the one hand, diabetes can increase the severity of periodontitis, and on the other hand, periodontitis can negatively impact glycemic control in adults with diabetes.
Studies have shown that treating periodontitis can improve glycemic control in adults with diabetes. The mechanism by which periodontitis affects glycemic control is not fully understood, but it is believed that periodontal inflammation may contribute to insulin resistance and increase blood glucose levels.
Treatment of periodontitis, which includes scaling and root planing, antibiotics, and lifestyle modifications, can help reduce periodontal inflammation and improve glycemic control. In fact, a systematic review and meta-analysis published in the Journal of Clinical Periodontology found that treatment of periodontitis resulted in significant improvements in HbA1c levels in patients with diabetes.
Therefore, it is important for adults with diabetes to maintain good oral health, including regular dental check-ups and treatment of periodontitis, to help manage their diabetes and improve their overall health.

data.question: In women trying to conceive by intrauterine insemination or sexual intercourse, what are the effects of progesterone as luteal phase support?
data.gold_answer: In women trying to conceive by intrauterine insemination or sexual intercourse, it is uncertain whether the addition of progesterone as luteal support results in a higher live birth/ongoing pregnancy rate or lower miscarriage rate compared with no progesterone. Low‐certainty evidence suggests little to no improvement in live birth/ongoing pregnancy rate with the use of progesterone versus placebo or no treatment (155 vs 141 per 1000 women; all results on average). Low‐certainty evidence suggests little to no improvement in live birth/ongoing pregnancy rate with the addition of progesterone in women undergoing ovarian stimulation with gonadotrophin, gonadotrophin plus oral ovulogens, or oral ovulogens alone. It is unclear whether the use of progesterone reduces miscarriage rate per pregnancy, as the certainty of evidence was low (130 vs 185 per 1000 pregnancies) and the results were similar, irrespective of the stimulation protocol used. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that the clinical pregnancy rate may be higher following the use of vaginal progesterone in women undergoing stimulation with gonadotrophin, gonadotrophin plus oral ovulogens, or oral ovulogens alone. Low‐certainty evidence suggests no difference in multiple pregnancy rate following the addition of progesterone. None of the trials reported adverse events or ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome rates. For a comparison of different doses and routes of administration of progesterone as luteal phase support for women trying to conceive by intrauterine insemination or sexual intercourse, see CCA 4174 .
data.gold_answer_terms:
PROGESTERONE (progesterone): A hormone produced as a result of ovulation. It prepares the lining of the womb to enable a fertilised egg to implant there.
MISCARRIAGE (miscarriage): The unplanned ending of a pregnancy before 23 completed weeks.
PLACEBO (placebo): an inactive substance; a pill/liquid that contains no medicine
GONADOTROPHINS (gonadotrophins): Hormones that help ovulation in women and the production of sperm in men. See also follicle-stimulating hormone, human chorionic gonadotrophin and luteinising hormone.
PROTOCOL (protocol): plan of study
CLINICAL (clinical): pertaining to medical care
SYNDROME (syndrome): a condition characterized by a set of symptoms

Progesterone as luteal phase support in women trying to conceive by intrauterine insemination or sexual intercourse helps to:
* Maintain the thickness of the uterine lining, which is essential for embryo implantation
* Enhance the receptivity of the uterus to the fertilized egg
* Increase the chances of successful implantation and pregnancy
* Reduce the risk of miscarriage
* Improve the overall outcome of assisted reproductive techniques (ART) such as IUI and IVF.

data.question: How do portosystemic shunts compare with endoscopic interventions for prevention of rebleeding in adults with cirrhosis?
data.gold_answer: Very low‐certainty evidence does not allow conclusions to be drawn about the benefits and harms of portosystemic shunts compared with endoscopy interventions for people with cirrhosis and previous hypertensive portal bleeding. After average follow‐up of about two to three years, the comparative effects of portosystemic shunts versus endoscopy interventions on all‐cause mortality, rebleeding, and acute or chronic hepatic encephalopathy were very uncertain. Although reviewers did report fewer cases of rebleeding and more cases of acute hepatic encephalopathy with portosystemic shunts, no meaningful conclusions could be drawn about effects of portosystemic shunts versus endoscopy interventions on complications, as complications were not reported adequately in most trials. No trials have reported on health‐related quality of life.
data.gold_answer_terms:
HYPERTENSION (hypertension): high blood pressure
MORTALITY (mortality): death
ACUTE (acute): new, recent, sudden, urgent
CHRONIC (chronic): continuing for a long time, ongoing
COMPLICATIONS (complications): Problems that develop after an operation, treatment or illness.
data.llm_answer:
Portosystemic shunts and endoscopic interventions are both used to prevent rebleeding in adults with cirrhosis, but they have different advantages and disadvantages.
Portosystemic shunts are surgical procedures that create a new connection between the portal vein and another vein, such as the inferior vena cava, to reduce pressure in the portal vein and prevent bleeding. They are effective in reducing the risk of rebleeding, but they can have serious complications such as infection, sepsis, and liver failure.
Endoscopic interventions, on the other hand, are minimally invasive procedures that use an endoscope to locate and treat bleeding vessels in the esophagus or stomach. They are less invasive than portosystemic shunts and have fewer complications, but they may not be as effective in preventing rebleeding in all patients.
In summary, portosystemic shunts are more effective in preventing rebleeding but have more complications, while endoscopic interventions are less invasive but may not be as effective in all patients. The choice between the two depends on the patient's individual circumstances and the severity of their condition.

data.llm_answer:
Portosystemic shunts and endoscopic interventions are both treatment options for preventing rebleeding in adults with cirrhosis, but they have different mechanisms of action and outcomes.
Portosystemic shunts are surgical procedures that create a new connection between the portal vein and another vein, such as the inferior vena cava, to redirect blood flow and reduce pressure in the portal vein. This can help prevent rebleeding from esophageal varices, which are enlarged veins in the esophagus that can rupture and bleed in people with cirrhosis.
Endoscopic interventions, on the other hand, are minimally invasive procedures that use an endoscope (a flexible tube with a camera and light on the end) to visualize the esophageal varices and treat them with various techniques, such as ligation (tying off the varices), sclerotherapy (injecting a solution to scar the varices), or banding (placing a small band around the varices to constrict them).
Both portosystemic shunts and endoscopic interventions have been shown to be effective in preventing rebleeding in adults with cirrhosis, but they have different advantages and disadvantages. Portosystemic shunts are more invasive and require a longer recovery time, but they can provide more durable protection against rebleeding and may be more effective in patients with severe liver disease. Endoscopic interventions, on the other hand, are less invasive and have a faster recovery time, but they may need to be repeated more frequently to maintain their effectiveness.
The choice between portosystemic shunts and endoscopic interventions depends on various factors, such as the severity of liver disease, the size and location of the esophageal varices, and the patient's overall health status. Your doctor will be able to discuss the risks and benefits of each option with you and help determine the best course of treatment for your individual situation.

data.question: What are the effects of standardized tobacco packaging design in reducing tobacco use among adults?
data.gold_answer: Standardized tobacco packaging designs may be beneficial in decreasing prevalence of tobacco use and increasing smoking cessation attempts. Furthermore, these designs may result in increased concealment behaviors. Low‐certainty evidence from one large observational study supports the standardization of tobacco packaging to reduce the prevalence of tobacco use (from 19% to 18.5% one year after implementation). Further, use of standardized tobacco packaging was associated with increased numbers of people attempting to quit smoking; this was reported as an increase of 20% to 27% in one observational study, and as an increase in the number of calls to a smoking cessation helpline by 78% in another. Limited evidence from eight observational studies reported increased avoidance behaviors, such as concealing standardized cigarette packs or using a different container for cigarettes, avoiding looking at or thinking about the labels, and concealing standardized packs while in public. For change in tobacco consumption and perception of harm, studies reported mixed results, precluding a firm conclusion. Reviewers found no evidence assessing uptake, cessation, or relapse prevention. Only one country had implemented standardized packaging at the time of this review.
data.gold_answer_terms:
CESSATION (cessation): stopping
ASSESS (assess): to learn about, measure, evaluate, look at
UPTAKE (uptake): absorbing and taking in of a substance by living tissue
RELAPSE (relapse): the return of a disease
data.llm_answer:
Standardized tobacco packaging design, also known as plain packaging, has been shown to reduce tobacco use among adults by:
1. Reducing the appeal of tobacco products: Standardized packaging eliminates the use of attractive colors, logos, and graphics that make tobacco products more appealing to consumers.
2. Increasing the noticeability of health warnings: Standardized packaging requires larger and more prominent health warnings, which can increase awareness of the risks associated with tobacco use.
3. Reducing the perceived quality of tobacco products: Standardized packaging can make tobacco products appear less premium or desirable, which can reduce their appeal to consumers.
4. Increasing the perceived harm of tobacco products: Standardized packaging can make tobacco products appear more harmful or dangerous, which can increase the perceived risk of using them.
5. Encouraging smokers to quit: Standardized packaging can make smokers more aware of the health risks associated with tobacco use and encourage them to quit.
Overall, standardized tobacco packaging design can be an effective strategy for reducing tobacco use among adults by reducing the appeal of tobacco products and increasing awareness of the health risks associated with their use.

The WHO also notes that plain packaging is a cost-effective way to reduce tobacco use, as it eliminates the need for expensive advertising and promotion campaigns.

It's worth noting that the effectiveness of plain packaging in reducing tobacco use may vary depending on the specific design and implementation of the policy, as well as the broader tobacco control environment.
However, overall, plain packaging is considered to be a valuable tool in the fight against tobacco-related diseases.

data.question: How do short feeding intervals compare with long feeding intervals for bolus feedings in very preterm infants?
data.gold_answer: Low‐certainty evidence suggests there may be no clinically important differences between short and long feeding intervals for bolus feedings in very preterm infants. In neonates ranging from 1000 to 1499 g birth weight and 30 to 33 weeks' gestational age, low‐certainty evidence suggests that feed intervals of two hours (compared with three hours) resulted in no overall difference in time to achieve full enteral feeds (approximately ‐0.62 days). In extremely low birth weight infants (< 1000 g), short feeding intervals resulted in fewer days to achieve full enteral feeding (approximately three days fewer); these results should be interpreted with caution owing to the small sample size in the analysis. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that two‐hour (short) feeding intervals resulted in a longer time to regain birth weight (approximately 1.15 days longer). Reviewers found little to no difference between two‐hour and three‐hour intervals in duration of hospital stay, incidence of mortality, culture‐positive sepsis, necrotizing enterocolitis, hypoglycemia, or feed intolerance.

Short feeding intervals (e.g., 1-2 hours) for bolus feedings in very preterm infants (less than 32 weeks gestational age) are generally associated with better outcomes compared to long feeding intervals (e.g., 4-6 hours).
Several studies have shown that short feeding intervals in very preterm infants lead to:
1. Improved weight gain: Short feeding intervals result in more frequent, smaller feedings, which can help very preterm infants achieve optimal weight gain.
2. Reduced risk of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): NEC is a serious intestinal condition that can occur in preterm infants. Short feeding intervals may reduce the risk of NEC by preventing the buildup of formula or breastmilk in the gut.
3. Better glucose control: Frequent feedings can help maintain stable blood sugar levels in very preterm infants, who may have immature glucose regulation.
4. Improved gut maturation: Short feeding intervals can promote the maturation of the gut and reduce the risk of gut-related complications, such as gut dysmotility and intestinal perforation.
5. Reduced risk of infection: Short feeding intervals may reduce the risk of infection by minimizing the amount of time that the infant's gut is exposed to potential pathogens.
However, it's important to note that the optimal feeding interval for very preterm infants may vary depending on the individual infant's needs and medical condition. It's essential to consult with a healthcare provider to determine the most appropriate feeding schedule for your baby.

data.question: For people with chronic liver disease, what is the diagnostic test accuracy of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for the detection of resectable hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)?
data.gold_answer: For people with chronic liver disease, when pathology following orthotopic liver transplantation or histology was used as the reference standard, average sensitivities of MRI for the detection of resectable HCC ranged from 44% to 96%, and specificities ranged from 77% to 100%. The pooled estimate for sensitivity was 84.3%, and specificity was 92.9% (low‐certainty evidence). Using these estimates, reviewers reported that for every 1000 people tested, the average number of resectable HCC wrongly diagnosed could be 45, and 57 cases could be missed, at a prevalence of 36% (probability of HCC increases to 87% after a positive test and decreases to 9% after a negative test); values at 56% prevalence could be 31 and 88, respectively (probability of HCC increases to 94% after a positive test and decreases to 18% after a negative test); and at 66% prevalence could be 24 and 104, respectively (probability of HCC increases to 96% after a positive test and decreases to 25% after a negative test). PICOS
data.gold_answer_terms:
CHRONIC (chronic): continuing for a long time, ongoing
DISEASE (disease): An abnormal condition in the body causing harm.
MRI (mri): magnetic resonance imaging, diagnostic pictures of the inside of the body, created using magnetic rather than x-ray energy
RESECT (resect): remove or cut out surgically
TESTES (testes): male sex glands
data.llm_answer: The diagnostic test accuracy of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for the detection of resectable hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in people with chronic liver disease is moderate to high, with a sensitivity ranging from 60-90% and a specificity ranging from 80-90%. However, MRI may not be able to detect small tumors or those in the early stages of development. Therefore, it is important to use MRI in combination with other diagnostic tests, such as alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and des-gamma-carboxyprothrombin (DCP), to improve the accuracy of HCC diagnosis.

data.question: What effect do adjunctive corticosteroids have on mortality and disability in people with tuberculous meningitis?
data.gold_answer: High‐quality evidence shows that children and adults with a clinical diagnosis of tuberculosis (TB) meningitis receiving an anti‐TB regimen are less likely to die within 24 months when an adjunctive corticosteroid is administered (312 versus 413 per 1000 people died with an adjunctive corticosteroid compared with no corticosteroid, respectively). Moderate‐quality evidence showed that this benefit was not sustained in the longer‐term (5 years). Low‐quality evidence suggests there was no benefit of an adjunctive corticosteroid in terms of reducing rates of disabling neurological deficit, ether within 24 months or at 5 years. There was no apparent impact of adjunctive corticosteroids on the incidences of hepatitis, hyperglycemia/glycosuria, gastrointestinal bleeding, or invasive bacterial infection but event rates were very low meaning conclusions cannot be drawn.
data.gold_answer_terms:
CLINICAL (clinical): pertaining to medical care
DIAGNOSIS (diagnosis): The way a medical professional recognises a condition or disease.
MENINGITIS (meningitis): Inflammation in the brain caused by a virus or bacteria.
REGIMEN (regimen): pattern of giving treatment
CORTICOSTEROIDS (corticosteroids): A group of hormones which may be used to suppress the body’s immune response or to reduce inflammation. Also used during pregnancy in women who are thought may have their baby prematurely. They reduce the chance of the baby having problems from being born prematurely. See also steroids.
TERM (term): Between 37 and 42 weeks of pregnancy.
NEUROLOGICAL (neurological): pertaining to the nervous system
GASTROINTESTINAL (gastrointestinal): Relating to the stomach and intestine.
INVASIVE (invasive): A medical procedure when a cut is made to the body or an instrument is inserted.
data.llm_answer: Adjunctive corticosteroids have been shown to improve mortality and disability outcomes in people with tuberculous meningitis. Studies have consistently demonstrated that corticosteroids reduce the risk of death and disability in patients with tuberculous meningitis, particularly in those with severe disease. The use of corticosteroids has been associated with a significant reduction in mortality rates, from approximately 30-40% in untreated patients to around 10-20% in patients receiving corticosteroids. Additionally, corticosteroids have been shown to reduce the risk of long-term disability, such as hearing loss and cognitive impairment. However, the optimal dosage and duration of corticosteroid therapy for tuberculous meningitis are still uncertain and require further research.

data.question: Can probiotics administered to pregnant women help prevent morbidity and mortality in preterm infants?
data.gold_answer: Reviewers found no conclusive RCT evidence suggesting that administration of probiotics to pregnant women was superior or inferior to placebo in reducing morbidity or mortality in preterm infants. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that in pregnant women who received probiotics, the risk of preterm birth (< 37 weeks) and miscarriage/stillbirth was no more or less likely compared with those who did not receive probiotics. Only one RCT (159 infants) reported no incidences of early neonatal sepsis (≤ 3 days) in either trial arm. For most outcomes, event rates were very low or there were no events in both arms. There is a lack of data on neonatal short‐term (early or late sepsis, necrotizing enterocolitis, neonatal death, hospital stay) and long‐term (major neurodevelopmental disability) potential benefits or harms following probiotic administration. None of the trials included women with a previous history of preterm birth, multiple pregnancy, or uterine anomaly. Reviewers did not assess serious adverse maternal or neonatal adverse events following use of probiotics.
data.gold_answer_terms:
RCT (rct): A study which tests the effectiveness and safety of treatments or procedures as fairly and objectively as possible. By randomly assigning patients to different treatments for the same problem, the results can be assessed equally with the aim of discovering the best possible procedure for the condition.
PLACEBO (placebo): an inactive substance; a pill/liquid that contains no medicine
MORBIDITY (morbidity): undesired result or complication
MORTALITY (mortality): death
RISK (risk): The chance that an activity or hazard will give rise to harm. Risk is generally given in terms of numerical odds (1 in 10) or percentages (10%).
SEPSIS (sepsis): The immune system's overreaction to an infection or injury which can lead to tissue damage, organ failure, and death.
POTENTIAL (potential): possible
POTENTIATE (potentiate): increase or multiply the effect of a drug or toxin (poison) by giving another drug or toxin at the same time (sometimes an unintentional result)
POTENTIATOR (potentiator): an agent that helps another agent work better
ASSESS (assess): to learn about, measure, evaluate, look at
